Semi-Lagrangian Discountinuous Galerkin -- 1 D

Equation description

One-dimensional transport equation

Firstly, we consider the one-dimensional transport equation:

{ut+(a(x,t)â‹…u)x=0,xâˆˆ[xa,xb]u(x,0)=u0(x) \begin{equation} \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} u_t + (a(x,t)\cdot u)_x = 0, x\in [x_a,x_b] \\ u(x,0) = u_0(x) \\ \end{array} \right. \end{equation} {utâ€‹+(a(x,t)â‹…u)xâ€‹=0,xâˆˆ[xaâ€‹,xbâ€‹]u(x,0)=u0â€‹(x)â€‹â€‹â€‹

  • a(x,t)a(x,t)a(x,t) is continuous, and divides in xa=x12<x32<...<xM+12=xbx_a = x_{\frac{1}{2}}<x_{\frac{3}{2}}< ... < x_{M+\frac{1}{2}} = x_bxaâ€‹=x21â€‹â€‹<x23â€‹â€‹<...<xM+21â€‹â€‹=xbâ€‹
  • For jjj-iterm, denoted Ij=[xjâˆ’12,xj+12]I_j = [x_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}]Ijâ€‹=[xjâˆ’21â€‹â€‹,xj+21â€‹â€‹]
  • Center point: xj=xjâˆ’12+xj+122x_j = \frac{x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}+x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}}{2}xjâ€‹=2xjâˆ’21â€‹â€‹+xj+21â€‹â€‹â€‹
  • Iterm length: Î”xj=xj+12âˆ’xjâˆ’12\Delta x_j = x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}-x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}Î”xjâ€‹=xj+21â€‹â€‹âˆ’xjâˆ’21â€‹â€‹
  • The domain is partitioned by non-overlapping intervals, Î©=âˆªjIj\Omega=\cup_{j}I_{j}Î©=âˆªjâ€‹Ijâ€‹.
  • The mesh size is denoted h=maxâ¡jÎ”xjh = \max_{j}\Delta x_{j}h=maxjâ€‹Î”xjâ€‹.
  • n-th time level with Î”tn=tn+1âˆ’tn\Delta t^{n} = t^{n+1}-t^{n}Î”tn=tn+1âˆ’tn

The preceding equations (2), presented in adjective form, maintain a constant solution along a characteristic trajectory. Subsequently, as demonstrated in, it can be established that:

Prove for (3) One-dimentional Reynolds transport theorem

According to one-dimentional Reynolds transport theorem,

ddxâˆ«a(t)b(t)f(x,t)dx=âˆ«a(t)b(t)âˆ‚f(x,t)âˆ‚tdx+(âˆ‚b(t)âˆ‚tf(b(t),t)âˆ’âˆ‚a(t)âˆ‚tf(a(t),t)) \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dx}\int_{a(t)}^{b(t)}f(x,t)dx = \int_{a(t)}^{b(t)}\frac{\partial f(x,t)}{\partial t}dx + (\frac{\partial b(t)}{\partial t}f(b(t),t) - \frac{\partial a(t)}{\partial t}f(a(t),t)) \end{equation} dxdâ€‹âˆ«a(t)b(t)â€‹f(x,t)dx=âˆ«a(t)b(t)â€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚f(x,t)â€‹dx+(âˆ‚tâˆ‚b(t)â€‹f(b(t),t)âˆ’âˆ‚tâˆ‚a(t)â€‹f(a(t),t))â€‹â€‹

ddtâˆ«Ij~(t)u(x,t)Ïˆ(x,t)dx=0 \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt}\int_{\widetilde{I_j}(t)}u(x,t)\psi(x,t)dx = 0 \end{equation} dtdâ€‹âˆ«Ijâ€‹â€‹(t)â€‹u(x,t)Ïˆ(x,t)dx=0â€‹â€‹

where ut(x,t)=du(x,t)dtu_t(x,t) = \frac{d u(x,t)}{dt}utâ€‹(x,t)=dtdu(x,t)â€‹ and dxdt=a(a,t)\frac{dx}{dt} = a(a,t)dtdxâ€‹=a(a,t), then

âˆ‚xâˆ‚ududt=a(a,t)â†’dudt=a(x,t)âˆ‚uâˆ‚t \frac{\partial{x}}{\partial{u}} \frac{du}{dt} = a(a,t) \xrightarrow{} \frac{du}{dt} = a(x,t)\frac{\partial{u}}{\partial{t}} âˆ‚uâˆ‚xâ€‹dtduâ€‹=a(a,t)â€‹dtduâ€‹=a(x,t)âˆ‚tâˆ‚uâ€‹

Given unâˆˆVhku^n \in V_h^kunâˆˆVhkâ€‹, we seek un+1âˆˆVhku^{n+1}\in V_h^kun+1âˆˆVhkâ€‹, such that for âˆ€Î¨âˆˆPk(Ij),j=1,...,k\forall \Psi \in P^k (I_j),j=1,...,kâˆ€Î¨âˆˆPk(Ijâ€‹),j=1,...,kã€‚ An SL time discretization of equation(3) leads to

where Ijâˆ—=[xjâˆ’12âˆ—,xj+12âˆ—]I^{*}_{j} = [x^{*}_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x^{*}_{j+\frac{1}{2}}]Ijâˆ—â€‹=[xjâˆ’21â€‹âˆ—â€‹,xj+21â€‹âˆ—â€‹] with xjÂ±12âˆ—x^{*}_{j\pm \frac{1}{2}}xjÂ±21â€‹âˆ—â€‹ being the foots of trajectory emanating from (xjÂ±12âˆ—,tn+1)(x^{*}_{j\pm \frac{1}{2}},t^{n+1})(xjÂ±21â€‹âˆ—â€‹,tn+1) at the time tnt^ntn. Then, update the numerical solution un+1u^{n+1}un+1.

Implementation

Step 1

Initially, we select k+1k+1k+1 interpolation points xj,px_{j,p}xj,pâ€‹, where p=0,...,kp = 0,...,kp=0,...,k(æ­¤æ—¶0åˆ°kå°±æ­£å¥½æ˜¯k+1ä¸ª), empolying methods like Gauss-Lobatto points within the interval IjI_jIjâ€‹.

Gauss-Lobatto

Utilizing Gaussian quadrature with a weighting function W(x)=1W(x)=1W(x)=1, encompassing the endpoints of the interval [âˆ’1,1][-1,1][âˆ’1,1], involves a total of n abscissas, resulting in r=nâˆ’2r=n-2r=nâˆ’2 free abscissas. The abscissas are symmetric about the origin, and the general formula is given by:

âˆ«âˆ’11f(x)dx=w1f(âˆ’1)+wnf(1)+âˆ‘i=2nâˆ’1wif(xi). \begin{equation} \int_{-1}^{1}f(x)dx = w_1 f(-1) + w_n f(1) + \sum_{i=2}^{n-1}w_if(x_i). \end{equation} âˆ«âˆ’11â€‹f(x)dx=w1â€‹f(âˆ’1)+wnâ€‹f(1)+i=2âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹wiâ€‹f(xiâ€‹).â€‹â€‹

The unrestricted abscissas xix_ixiâ€‹ for i=2,...,nâˆ’1i=2, ..., n-1i=2,...,nâˆ’1 correspond to the roots of the derivative Pnâˆ’1â€²(x)P_{n-1}^{'}(x)Pnâˆ’1â€²â€‹(x), where P(x)P(x)P(x) represents a Legendre polynomial. The weights associated with these unrestricted abscissas are:

wi=âˆ’2n(1âˆ’xi2)Pn+1â€²â€²Pmâ€²(xi)=2n(nâˆ’1)[Pnâˆ’1(xi)]2 \begin{equation} w_i = - \frac{2n}{(1-x_i^2)P^{''}_{n+1}P^{'}_{m}(x_i)}= \frac{2}{n(n-1)[P_{n-1}(x_i)]^2} \end{equation} wiâ€‹=âˆ’(1âˆ’xi2â€‹)Pn+1â€²â€²â€‹Pmâ€²â€‹(xiâ€‹)2nâ€‹=n(nâˆ’1)[Pnâˆ’1â€‹(xiâ€‹)]22â€‹â€‹â€‹

and the endpoint are wi,n2n(nâˆ’1)w_{i,n}\frac{2}{n(n-1)}wi,nâ€‹n(nâˆ’1)2â€‹.

Subsequencetly, we determine the footpoints xj,qâˆ—x^{*}_{j,q}xj,qâˆ—â€‹ through numerical solutions to the trajectory equation.

dx(t)dt=a(x(t),t),Â withÂ x(tn+1)=xj,q \begin{equation} \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = a(x(t),t), \text{ with } x(t^{n+1}) = x_{j,q} \end{equation} dtdx(t)â€‹=a(x(t),t),Â withÂ x(tn+1)=xj,qâ€‹â€‹â€‹

    ! assemble gauss lobatto of an upstream element
    ! prepare for interpolating the test function.
    do i = 1,nx
        ! consider an upstream element
        p => element_star(i)
        pe => element(i)
        
        if( nk>0 )then
            p%xgl_star(1) =  vertex_star(i)%coor
            p%xgl_star(nk+1) = vertex_star(i+1)%coor
            !
            if( nk>1 )then
                pe%xgl(1) = vertex(i)%coor
                pe%xgl(nk+1) = vertex(i+1)%coor

                do ii = 2,nk
                    pe%xgl(ii) = pe%xgl(1)+( 1.0/2. + gau_lob(ii,1) )*(  pe%xgl(nk+1)-pe%xgl(1) )

                    call runge_kutta( pe%xgl(ii) , p%xgl_star(ii)   ,dt)
                enddo

            endif
        endif
    enddo

Runge-Kutta 4

Achieved using the Runge-Kutta method as follow,

{xj,qâˆ—=xj,qâˆ’Î”t6(k1+2k2+2k3+k4)k1=a(xj,q,tn+1),k2=a(xj,qâˆ’Î”t2k1,tn+12),Â whereÂ tn+12=tn+12Î”tk3=a(xj,qâˆ’Î”t2k2,tn+12),Â whereÂ tn+12=tn+12Î”tk4=a(xj,qâˆ’Î”tk3,tn) \begin{equation} \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} x^{*}_{j,q}=x_{j,q}-\frac{\Delta t}{6}(k_1+2k_2+2k_3+k_4) \\ k_1 = a(x_{j,q},t^{n+1}),\\ k_2 = a(x_{j,q}-\frac{\Delta t}{2}k_1,t^{n+\frac{1}{2}}), \text{ where } t^{n+\frac{1}{2}} = t^{n}+\frac{1}{2}\Delta t\\ k_3 = a(x_{j,q}-\frac{\Delta t}{2}k_2, t^{n+\frac{1}{2}}),\text{ where } t^{n+\frac{1}{2}} = t^{n}+\frac{1}{2}\Delta t\\ k_4 = a(x_{j,q}-\Delta t k_3, t^{n}) \end{array} \right. \end{equation} â©â¨â§â€‹xj,qâˆ—â€‹=xj,qâ€‹âˆ’6Î”tâ€‹(k1â€‹+2k2â€‹+2k3â€‹+k4â€‹)k1â€‹=a(xj,qâ€‹,tn+1),k2â€‹=a(xj,qâ€‹âˆ’2Î”tâ€‹k1â€‹,tn+21â€‹),Â whereÂ tn+21â€‹=tn+21â€‹Î”tk3â€‹=a(xj,qâ€‹âˆ’2Î”tâ€‹k2â€‹,tn+21â€‹),Â whereÂ tn+21â€‹=tn+21â€‹Î”tk4â€‹=a(xj,qâ€‹âˆ’Î”tk3â€‹,tn)â€‹â€‹â€‹

ahieves fifth-order accuracy O(h5)O(h^5)O(h5). Since for RK4, the local truncation error is on the order of O(h5)O(h^5)O(h5), where hhh is the step size.

Step 2

Recalling that the test function Ïˆ(x,t)\psi(x,t)Ïˆ(x,t) resolves the final-value problem and consequently remains constant along the characteristics i.e., Ïˆ(xj,qâˆ—)=Î¨(xj,q)\psi(x^{*}_{j,q}) = \Psi(x_{j,q})Ïˆ(xj,qâˆ—â€‹)=Î¨(xj,qâ€‹). Our next step is to ascertain the unique polynomial Ïˆâˆ—(x)\psi^{*}(x)Ïˆâˆ—(x) of degree kkk. This polynomial is chosen such that it interpolates Ïˆ(x,tn)\psi(x,t^n)Ïˆ(x,tn) with the pairs (xj,qâˆ—,Î¨(xj,q))(x^{*}_{j,q},\Psi(x_{j,q}))(xj,qâˆ—â€‹,Î¨(xj,qâ€‹)) for q=0,â€¦,kq=0, \ldots, kq=0,â€¦,k.

we assume that Ïˆâˆ—(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+â€¦+akxk\psi^{*}(x)=a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \ldots + a_k x^{k}Ïˆâˆ—(x)=a0â€‹+a1â€‹x+a2â€‹x2+â€¦+akâ€‹xk, and Ïˆâˆ—(x)\psi^{*}(x)Ïˆâˆ—(x) satisfies,

{a0+a1xj,0âˆ—+a2xj,0âˆ—2+â€¦+akxj,0âˆ—k=Î¨(xj,0)a0+a1xj,1âˆ—+a2xj,1âˆ—2+â€¦+akxj,1âˆ—k=Î¨(xj,1)â‹®a0+a1xj,kâˆ—+a2xj,kâˆ—2+â€¦+akxj,kâˆ—k=Î¨(xj,k) \begin{equation} \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} a_0 + a_1 x^{*}_{j,0} + a_2 x^{*\quad2}_{j,0} + \ldots + a_k x^{*\quad k}_{j,0} = \Psi(x_{j,0})\\ a_0 + a_1 x^{*}_{j,1} + a_2 x^{*\quad2}_{j,1} + \ldots + a_k x^{*\quad k}_{j,1} = \Psi(x_{j,1})\\ \vdots \\ a_0 + a_1 x^{*}_{j,k} + a_2 x^{*\quad2}_{j,k} + \ldots + a_k x^{*\quad k}_{j,k} = \Psi(x_{j,k})\\ \end{array} \right. \end{equation} â©â¨â§â€‹a0â€‹+a1â€‹xj,0âˆ—â€‹+a2â€‹xj,0âˆ—2â€‹+â€¦+akâ€‹xj,0âˆ—kâ€‹=Î¨(xj,0â€‹)a0â€‹+a1â€‹xj,1âˆ—â€‹+a2â€‹xj,1âˆ—2â€‹+â€¦+akâ€‹xj,1âˆ—kâ€‹=Î¨(xj,1â€‹)â‹®a0â€‹+a1â€‹xj,kâˆ—â€‹+a2â€‹xj,kâˆ—2â€‹+â€¦+akâ€‹xj,kâˆ—kâ€‹=Î¨(xj,kâ€‹)â€‹â€‹â€‹

Or we need to use the orthogonal polynomial 1d form or Legendre polynomials

Legendre polynomials in [-1,1]

Î¾=2(xâˆ’xj)hjâˆˆ[âˆ’1,1],âˆ€xâˆˆIj \begin{equation} \xi = \frac{2(x-x_j)}{h_j} \in[-1,1], \forall x\in I_{j} \end{equation} Î¾=hjâ€‹2(xâˆ’xjâ€‹)â€‹âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1],âˆ€xâˆˆIjâ€‹â€‹â€‹

The first several polynomials are defined as

p0(Î¾)=1,p1(Î¾)=Î¾,p2(Î¾)=12(3Î¾2âˆ’1),p3(Î¾)=12(5Î¾3âˆ’3Î¾) p_0(\xi) = 1, p_1(\xi) = \xi, p_2(\xi) = \frac{1}{2}(3\xi^{2}-1), \\ p_3(\xi) = \frac{1}{2}(5\xi^{3}-3\xi) p0â€‹(Î¾)=1,p1â€‹(Î¾)=Î¾,p2â€‹(Î¾)=21â€‹(3Î¾2âˆ’1),p3â€‹(Î¾)=21â€‹(5Î¾3âˆ’3Î¾)

In the each interval IjI_{j}Ijâ€‹, we can take the local functions {Ïˆl(x)}l=0l=k\{\psi_{l}(x)\}_{l=0}^{l=k}{Ïˆlâ€‹(x)}l=0l=kâ€‹

Ïˆl(x)=pl(Î¾),xâˆˆIj \psi_{l}(x) = p_{l}(\xi),x\in I_{j} Ïˆlâ€‹(x)=plâ€‹(Î¾),xâˆˆIjâ€‹

Then we can let,

A=[1xj,0âˆ—xj,0âˆ—2â‹¯xj,0âˆ—k1xj,1âˆ—xj,1âˆ—2â‹¯xj,1âˆ—kâ‹®â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®1xj,kâˆ—xj,kâˆ—2â‹¯xj,kâˆ—k] A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & x^{*}_{j,0} & x^{*\quad2}_{j,0} &\cdots& x^{*\quad k}_{j,0} \\ 1 & x^{*}_{j,1} & x^{*\quad2}_{j,1} &\cdots& x^{*\quad k}_{j,1} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots\\ 1 & x^{*}_{j,k} & x^{*\quad2}_{j,k} &\cdots& x^{*\quad k}_{j,k} \\ \end{bmatrix} A=â€‹11â‹®1â€‹xj,0âˆ—â€‹xj,1âˆ—â€‹â‹®xj,kâˆ—â€‹â€‹xj,0âˆ—2â€‹xj,1âˆ—2â€‹â‹®xj,kâˆ—2â€‹â€‹â‹¯â‹¯â‹±â‹¯â€‹xj,0âˆ—kâ€‹xj,1âˆ—kâ€‹â‹®xj,kâˆ—kâ€‹â€‹â€‹

X=[a0a1â‹®ak],B=[Î¨(xj,0)Î¨(xj,1)â‹®Î¨(xj,k)] X = \begin{bmatrix} a_0 \\ a_1 \\ \vdots \\ a_k \end{bmatrix}, B = \begin{bmatrix} \Psi(x_{j,0})\\\Psi(x_{j,1})\\\vdots\\\Psi(x_{j,k})\\ \end{bmatrix} X=â€‹a0â€‹a1â€‹â‹®akâ€‹â€‹â€‹,B=â€‹Î¨(xj,0â€‹)Î¨(xj,1â€‹)â‹®Î¨(xj,kâ€‹)â€‹â€‹

Then system (11) can be expressed in matrix from AX=BAX=BAX=B. Then we need to find the coefficients a0,a1,â‹¯aka_0,a_1,\cdots a_ka0â€‹,a1â€‹,â‹¯akâ€‹ of the Ïˆâˆ—(x)\psi^{*}(x)Ïˆâˆ—(x).

Step 3

Detect interval/sub-intervals within Ijâˆ—=âˆªlIj,lâˆ—I^{*}_{j} = \cup_{l}I^{*}_{j,l}Ijâˆ—â€‹=âˆªlâ€‹Ij,lâˆ—â€‹, which are the intersections bewteen Ijâˆ—I^{*}_{j}Ijâˆ—â€‹ and the grid elements(l is the index for sub-interval). Here lll serves as the index for the sub-interval. For each interval, there may exist two sub-intervals: Ij,1âˆ—=[xjâˆ’12âˆ—,xjâˆ’12]I^{*}_{j,1}=[x^{*}_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}]Ij,1âˆ—â€‹=[xjâˆ’21â€‹âˆ—â€‹,xjâˆ’21â€‹â€‹] and Ij,2=[xjâˆ’12,xj+12âˆ—]I_{j,2}=[x_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x^{*}_{j+\frac{1}{2}}]Ij,2â€‹=[xjâˆ’21â€‹â€‹,xj+21â€‹âˆ—â€‹], Like the picture below.

Firstly, for each result of xjâˆ’12âˆ—x^{*}_{j-\frac{1}{2}}xjâˆ’21â€‹âˆ—â€‹ or xj+12âˆ—x^{*}_{j+\frac{1}{2}}xj+21â€‹âˆ—â€‹ we record the distance with the original start point. Then, we calculate the number of subinterval by (vertex_star(i)%coor-xleft)/dx.

do i = 1 ,nx+1
    call runge_kutta( vertex(i)%coor ,  vertex_star(i)%coor  ,dt)
    !ceiling æ˜¯å‘ä¸Šå–æ•´
    vertex_star(i)%id = ceiling( (vertex_star(i)%coor-xleft)/dx )
enddo

And in the implementation, we use a new data structure and create a pointer to obtain all xâˆ—x^{*}xâˆ—.

do i = 1,nx
    ! consider an upstream element
    p => element_star(i)
    p%point_origin = vertex_star(i)
    p%point_end = vertex_star(i+1)

    call search_segment(p)
enddo

After that, we use the sgement_search function, to get all subinterval of an upstream element.

mx = p%point_end%id - p%point_origin%id ! mxä¹Ÿè¡¨ç¤ºx*ä¸­æœ‰å‡ ä¸ªç‚¹

p%point_inter(0) = p%point_origin !x* çš„èµ·å§‹ç‚¹
p%point_inter(1+mx) = p%point_end !å¦‚æœx* éƒ½åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªintervalé‡Œï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆmx = 0, ç‚¹å°±æ˜¯ p%point_inter(1)
p%nsub = mx+1 !x* æœ‰å‡ ä¸ªsubinterval

if(mx .ne. 0)then
    do kk = 1 , mx
        inter = p%point_origin%id + kk !æ˜¯ç¬¬å‡ ä¸ªx
        p%point_inter(kk)%coor = xgrid( inter ) !é€šè¿‡xgridæ‰¾åˆ°xçš„å€¼
        p%point_inter(kk)%id = inter !è®°å½•èµ·å§‹ç‚¹å¯¹åº”çš„ä½ç½®
    enddo
endif
!è®°å½•æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªsubintervalèµ·å§‹ç‚¹ï¼Œç»ˆç‚¹&èµ·å§‹ç‚¹å¯¹åº”çš„ä½ç½®
do kk = 1 , 1 + mx
    p%segment(kk)%porigin = p%point_inter(kk-1)
    p%segment(kk)%pend = p%point_inter(kk)
    p%segment(kk)%id = p%point_inter(kk-1)%id
enddo

Finally, we obtain Ijâˆ—=âˆªlIj,lâˆ—I^{*}_{j} = \cup_{l}I^{*}_{j,l}Ijâˆ—â€‹=âˆªlâ€‹Ij,lâˆ—â€‹

Step 4

Using the discontinuous Galerkin method to obtain uhn+1âˆˆPk(Ij)u^{n+1}_{h}\in P^{k}(I_j)uhn+1â€‹âˆˆPk(Ijâ€‹), such that the above equation holds for any Î¨hâˆˆPk(Ij)\Psi_{h}\in P^{k}(I_j)Î¨hâ€‹âˆˆPk(Ijâ€‹).

In the each interval IjI_{j}Ijâ€‹, we can take the local functions {Ïˆl(x)}l=0l=k\{\psi_{l}(x)\}_{l=0}^{l=k}{Ïˆlâ€‹(x)}l=0l=kâ€‹

Ïˆl(x)=pl(Î¾),xâˆˆIj \begin{equation} \psi_{l}(x) = p_{l}(\xi),x\in I_{j} \end{equation} Ïˆlâ€‹(x)=plâ€‹(Î¾),xâˆˆIjâ€‹â€‹â€‹

where pl(Î¾)p_{l}(\xi)plâ€‹(Î¾) is the Legendre polynomials in [âˆ’1,1][-1,1][âˆ’1,1].

The basis functions satisfy the following property:

  • L2âˆ’L^2-L2âˆ’orthogonality

âˆ«âˆ’11pm(Î¾)pn(Î¾)dÎ¾=22n+1Î´mn,âˆ€m,n=0,1,...,k \begin{equation} \int_{-1}^{1}p_{m}(\xi)p_{n}(\xi)d\xi = \frac{2}{2n+1}\delta_{mn},\forall m,n = 0,1,...,k \end{equation} âˆ«âˆ’11â€‹pmâ€‹(Î¾)pnâ€‹(Î¾)dÎ¾=2n+12â€‹Î´mnâ€‹,âˆ€m,n=0,1,...,kâ€‹â€‹

where Î´mn\delta_{mn}Î´mnâ€‹ is Kronecker delta,equal to 1 if m=nm = nm=n and to 0 otherwise. Then, the local basis functions {Ïˆl(x)}\{\psi_{l}(x)\}{Ïˆlâ€‹(x)} in IjI_{j}Ijâ€‹

âˆ«IjÏˆm(x)Ïˆn(x)dx=âˆ«âˆ’11pm(Î¾)pn(Î¾)dÎ¾â‹…hj2=hj2n+1Î´mn \begin{equation} \int_{I_j}\psi_{m}(x)\psi_{n}(x)dx = \int_{-1}^{1}p_{m}(\xi)p_{n}(\xi)d\xi \cdot \frac{h_j}{2}= \frac{h_j}{2n+1}\delta_{mn} \end{equation} âˆ«Ijâ€‹â€‹Ïˆmâ€‹(x)Ïˆnâ€‹(x)dx=âˆ«âˆ’11â€‹pmâ€‹(Î¾)pnâ€‹(Î¾)dÎ¾â‹…2hjâ€‹â€‹=2n+1hjâ€‹â€‹Î´mnâ€‹â€‹â€‹

Where hjh_jhjâ€‹ is the mesh size for sub-interval and this formula means the Ïˆ\psiÏˆ is linear independent.

Therefore, uhn+1=Pk(Ij)u^{n+1}_{h} = P^{k}(I_j)uhn+1â€‹=Pk(Ijâ€‹) can be expressed with Ïˆm\psi_mÏˆmâ€‹

uhn+1=âˆ‘m=0kÎ±mn+1Ïˆm u^{n+1}_{h} = \sum_{m=0}^{k}\alpha_{m}^{n+1}\psi_m uhn+1â€‹=m=0âˆ‘kâ€‹Î±mn+1â€‹Ïˆmâ€‹

Step 5

For uh0u^{0}_huh0â€‹, in each element jjj, we can assume uh0=âˆ‘m=0kÎ±m0Ïˆn,Â ForÂ n=0,..,ku^{0}_{h} = \sum_{m=0}^{k} \alpha^{0}_{m}\psi_{n}, \text{ For }n=0,..,kuh0â€‹=âˆ‘m=0kâ€‹Î±m0â€‹Ïˆnâ€‹,Â ForÂ n=0,..,k

(u0,Ïˆn)=âˆ‘m=0Î±m0(Î¸m,Î¸n)=Î±m0hj2m+1Î´mn \begin{align} (u^{0},\psi_{n}) &=\sum_{m=0}\alpha_{m}^{0}(\theta_m,\theta_n) \\ &= \alpha_{m}^{0}\frac{h_j}{2m+1}\delta_{mn} \end{align} (u0,Ïˆnâ€‹)â€‹=m=0âˆ‘â€‹Î±m0â€‹(Î¸mâ€‹,Î¸nâ€‹)=Î±m0â€‹2m+1hjâ€‹â€‹Î´mnâ€‹â€‹â€‹

where we obtain (u0,Ïˆn)(u^{0},\psi_{n})(u0,Ïˆnâ€‹) by numerical integration,

Î±m0=(2m+1)(u0,Ïˆn)hj \begin{equation} \alpha_{m}^{0} = (2m+1) \frac{(u^{0},\psi_{n})}{h_j} \end{equation} Î±m0â€‹=(2m+1)hjâ€‹(u0,Ïˆnâ€‹)â€‹â€‹â€‹

Step 6

For each element jjj, we have

âˆ«Ijuhn+1Î¨hdx=âˆ«Ijâˆ—uhnÏˆndx=âˆ‘lâˆ«Ij,luhâˆ—Ïˆâˆ—dx \begin{equation} \int_{I_j} u^{n+1}_h \Psi_h dx = \int_{I^{*}_{j}}u^{n}_{h}\psi^{n}dx = \sum_{l}\int_{I_{j,l}}u^{*}_{h}\psi^{*}dx \end{equation} âˆ«Ijâ€‹â€‹uhn+1â€‹Î¨hâ€‹dx=âˆ«Ijâˆ—â€‹â€‹uhnâ€‹Ïˆndx=lâˆ‘â€‹âˆ«Ij,lâ€‹â€‹uhâˆ—â€‹Ïˆâˆ—dxâ€‹â€‹

Note that

mstj=âˆ«IjÏˆsÏˆtdx=hj2s+1Î´stbsj=âˆ‘lâˆ«Ij,luhnÏˆsâˆ—dx \begin{aligned} &m^{j}_{st} = \int_{I_j}\psi_s \psi_t dx = \frac{h_j}{2s+1}\delta_{st} \\ &b_{s}^{j} = \sum_{l}\int_{I_{j,l}}u^n_h\psi_s^* dx \\ \end{aligned} â€‹mstjâ€‹=âˆ«Ijâ€‹â€‹Ïˆsâ€‹Ïˆtâ€‹dx=2s+1hjâ€‹â€‹Î´stâ€‹bsjâ€‹=lâˆ‘â€‹âˆ«Ij,lâ€‹â€‹uhnâ€‹Ïˆsâˆ—â€‹dxâ€‹

The matrix is

[m00jm01jâ‹¯m0kjm10jm11jâ‹¯m1kjâ‹®â‹®â‹¯â‹®mk0jmk1jâ‹¯mkkj][Î±0j,n+1Î±1j,n+1â‹®Î±kj,n+1]=[b0jb1jâ‹®bkj] \begin{bmatrix} m_{00}^{j} & m_{01}^{j} &\cdots &m_{0k}^{j} \\ m_{10}^{j} & m_{11}^{j} &\cdots &m_{1k}^{j} \\ \vdots & \vdots &\cdots &\vdots \\ m_{k0}^{j} & m_{k1}^{j} &\cdots &m_{kk}^{j} \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \alpha_{0}^{j,n+1} \\ \alpha_{1}^{j,n+1} \\ \vdots \\ \alpha_{k}^{j,n+1} \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} b{0}^{j} \\ b{1}^{j} \\ \vdots \\ b{k}^{j} \\ \end{bmatrix} â€‹m00jâ€‹m10jâ€‹â‹®mk0jâ€‹â€‹m01jâ€‹m11jâ€‹â‹®mk1jâ€‹â€‹â‹¯â‹¯â‹¯â‹¯â€‹m0kjâ€‹m1kjâ€‹â‹®mkkjâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹Î±0j,n+1â€‹Î±1j,n+1â€‹â‹®Î±kj,n+1â€‹â€‹â€‹=â€‹b0jb1jâ‹®bkjâ€‹â€‹

Step 7

Mj=[mstj](k+1)Ã—(k+1),Â forÂ s,t=0,â‹¯â€‰,kBj=[bsj](k+1)Ã—1,Â forÂ s=0,â‹¯â€‰,kXj=[Î±sj,n+1](k+1)Ã—1,Â forÂ s=0,â‹¯â€‰,k \begin{aligned} &M^j = [m^{j}_{st}]_{(k+1)\times (k+1)}, \text{ for }s,t=0,\cdots,k\\ &B^j = [b_{s}^{j}]_{(k+1)\times 1}, \text{ for }s=0,\cdots,k\\ &X^j = [\alpha^{j,n+1}_{s}]_{(k+1)\times 1}, \text{ for }s=0,\cdots,k \end{aligned} â€‹Mj=[mstjâ€‹](k+1)Ã—(k+1)â€‹,Â forÂ s,t=0,â‹¯,kBj=[bsjâ€‹](k+1)Ã—1â€‹,Â forÂ s=0,â‹¯,kXj=[Î±sj,n+1â€‹](k+1)Ã—1â€‹,Â forÂ s=0,â‹¯,kâ€‹

Then the global stiffness matrix is

M=[M10â‹¯00M2â‹¯0â‹®â‹®â‹¯â‹®00â‹¯MN],Xn+1=[X1X2â‹®XN],B[B1B2â‹®BN] M = \begin{bmatrix} M^{1} & 0 &\cdots &0 \\ 0 & M^{2} &\cdots &0 \\ \vdots & \vdots &\cdots &\vdots \\ 0 & 0 &\cdots &M^{N} \\ \end{bmatrix} \\ , X^{n+1} = \begin{bmatrix} X^1 \\ X^2 \\ \vdots \\ X^N \\ \end{bmatrix} , B\begin{bmatrix} B^1 \\ B^2 \\ \vdots \\ B^N \\ \end{bmatrix} M=â€‹M10â‹®0â€‹0M2â‹®0â€‹â‹¯â‹¯â‹¯â‹¯â€‹00â‹®MNâ€‹â€‹,Xn+1=â€‹X1X2â‹®XNâ€‹â€‹,Bâ€‹B1B2â‹®BNâ€‹â€‹

Finally, we can solve the linear equatiuns systems

MXn+1=B \begin{equation} MX^{n+1} = B \end{equation} MXn+1=Bâ€‹â€‹
